validation_metadata.verification_method: Direct review of Washington Revised Code Chapter 42.56

rights_of_access.description: The Public Records Act must be liberally construed to promote maximum disclosure of public records. Exemptions are to be narrowly construed, with all doubts resolved in favor of disclosure.
rights_of_access.conditions: Courts must interpret ambiguities in favor of access; burden on agency to justify withholding
rights_of_access.applies_to: All interpretations of the Public Records Act
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This creates a strong presumption of openness and places burden on agencies to justify any withholding
rights_of_access.request_tips: Cite: 'Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.030 requires liberal construction favoring disclosure. All doubts must be resolved in favor of providing these records.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must respond to public records requests within five business days. The response must either provide the records, acknowledge receipt and provide a reasonable estimate of time needed, or deny the request with legal justification.
rights_of_access.conditions: 5 business days from receipt of request; must provide specific response (not generic acknowledgment); estimate must be reasonable
rights_of_access.applies_to: All Washington Public Records Act requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: One of the fastest response requirements nationally - 5 business days for initial substantive response
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert: 'Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.520 requires a substantive response within 5 business days - providing records, a reasonable timeline, or written denial with legal basis.'

rights_of_access.description: If records cannot be provided within 5 business days, agencies must provide a reasonable estimate of the time required to respond. The estimated timeline must be objectively reasonable based on request complexity, volume, and available resources.
rights_of_access.conditions: Estimate must be provided within 5 business days; additional time must be reasonable; agency must actually meet the estimated date
rights_of_access.applies_to: Complex or voluminous requests requiring more than 5 business days
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Courts scrutinize whether additional time is truly reasonable; agencies cannot provide indefinite estimates
rights_of_access.request_tips: If delayed: 'Please explain under Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.520 what makes [timeframe] a reasonable estimate for this request. Courts require objective justification.'

rights_of_access.description: For voluminous or complex requests, agencies must provide records on a rolling or installment basis as they become available. Agencies cannot delay entire production until all records are ready.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies when full response will take significant time; must provide records as they are identified and reviewed
rights_of_access.applies_to: Large or complex requests requiring extended processing time
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Rolling production prevents agencies from using volume as excuse for complete delay
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Please provide responsive records on a rolling basis under Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.080 as they become available, rather than waiting until entire request is complete.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies may charge only for actual costs of copying and the actual cost of staff time directly associated with scanning or converting records to requested format. The first $2.00 in costs is free. Fees cannot include overhead.
rights_of_access.conditions: First $2.00 free; cannot charge for search or review time (only actual copying/conversion costs); must provide itemized fee estimate
rights_of_access.applies_to: All requests for copies of public records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Standard paper copies typically 15 cents per page; electronic copies often minimal or free
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge fees: 'Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.120 limits charges to actual copying costs. First $2.00 must be waived. Please provide itemized fee breakdown.'

rights_of_access.description: If a request requires use of technology or expertise not customarily provided by the agency, the agency may charge actual costs of providing the service. However, routine electronic format conversion cannot be charged as 'customized service.'
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be truly customized service beyond routine agency capabilities; cannot use this to charge for standard electronic production
rights_of_access.applies_to: Requests requiring specialized technical work beyond routine records production
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies often overuse this provision; routine PDF or database exports are NOT customized services
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge customized charges: 'Converting records to PDF/Excel is routine, not customized service under Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.120(3). Please waive these charges.'

rights_of_access.description: If records exist in electronic format, agencies must provide them electronically when requested. Requesters may specify their preferred format (PDF, Excel, native format, etc.).
rights_of_access.conditions: Records must exist electronically; agency must be able to provide in requested format without unreasonable burden
rights_of_access.applies_to: All electronically maintained public records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Electronic delivery reduces costs and expedites access; agencies should default to electronic when available
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Please provide these electronic records in [PDF/Excel/native format] as permitted by Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.120(2)(b).'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies cannot refuse to provide electronic records because they are maintained in proprietary format. Agencies must either provide in the proprietary format or convert to an accessible format.
rights_of_access.conditions: Agency may charge actual cost of conversion if necessary; cannot use format as excuse to withhold
rights_of_access.applies_to: Electronic records in proprietary or specialized formats
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Proprietary software cannot be a barrier to access under Washington law
rights_of_access.request_tips: If format cited as barrier: 'Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.080 requires provision of electronic records regardless of proprietary format. Please provide or convert.'

rights_of_access.description: All persons have the right to inspect public records free of charge. Agencies may only charge for copies, not for inspection or the opportunity to review records before requesting duplication.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be during regular business hours; agency may supervise to protect records; no fees for inspection
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Inspection allows review without cost, helpful for determining which records to copy
rights_of_access.request_tips: State: 'I request to inspect these records without charge before deciding what to copy, as permitted by Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.080.'

rights_of_access.description: If only portions of a record are exempt, agencies must provide the non-exempt portions after redacting the exempt information. Partial exemptions do not justify withholding entire documents.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must identify and redact only exempt portions; must produce all non-exempt portions; must explain each redaction
rights_of_access.applies_to: Records containing both exempt and non-exempt information
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies must perform thorough segregability analysis; cannot take blanket withholding approach
rights_of_access.request_tips: Demand: 'Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.210(1) requires you to redact only exempt portions and provide the rest. Please perform complete segregability review.'

rights_of_access.description: All denials must be in writing, state the specific exemption claimed, and provide a brief explanation of how the exemption applies. Generic or verbal denials are legally insufficient.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be written; must cite specific statutory exemption; must explain application to requested records; must be signed by responsible official
rights_of_access.applies_to: All full or partial denials of public records requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Proper written denial is prerequisite to agency's ability to defend withholding in court
rights_of_access.request_tips: If improperly denied: 'Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.210(3) requires written denial with specific exemption and explanation. Please provide proper written denial or grant access.'

rights_of_access.description: Requesters may file suit to enjoin agencies from withholding records. Courts review de novo and may examine records in camera. Prevailing requesters must be awarded attorney fees and costs.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must have been denied access or received inadequate response; court reviews independently; fee award mandatory if requester prevails
rights_of_access.applies_to: All improperly withheld public records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Mandatory attorney fee recovery makes litigation financially viable; agencies face significant costs if they lose
rights_of_access.request_tips: For litigation: 'Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.550 requires courts to award attorney fees to prevailing requesters. Improper withholding will result in fee liability.'

rights_of_access.description: If a court finds an agency violated the Public Records Act, it must award a penalty between $5 and $100 per day from the date of non-compliance. This penalty is in addition to attorney fees and costs.
rights_of_access.conditions: Penalty assessed from date agency should have provided records; amount determined by court based on circumstances
rights_of_access.applies_to: Successful legal challenges to improper denials or delays
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Per diem penalty creates significant financial incentive for agency compliance
rights_of_access.request_tips: For violations: 'Courts must assess daily penalties under Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.550(4) for PRA violations. Each day of non-compliance increases your liability.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies cannot require requesters to provide identification or state the purpose of their request. The right to access is not conditioned on identity or intended use of records.
rights_of_access.conditions: Agency may request contact information for response purposes only; cannot condition access on ID or purpose statement
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public records requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This protects requester privacy and prevents discrimination based on identity or perceived purpose
rights_of_access.request_tips: If asked for ID/purpose: 'Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.080 does not require me to identify myself or state my purpose beyond providing contact information for your response.'

rights_of_access.description: The Public Records Act grants access to 'any person' without regard to residency, citizenship, or connection to Washington. Out-of-state and international requesters have equal rights.
rights_of_access.conditions: None - right extends to all persons
rights_of_access.applies_to: All Washington public records requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Courts have consistently rejected residency-based restrictions on access
rights_of_access.request_tips: If residency questioned: 'Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.030 grants any person access without residency requirement.'

rights_of_access.description: Each agency must appoint a public records officer responsible for implementing the Public Records Act. The officer's name and contact information must be publicly available.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must designate officer; must make contact information available; officer responsible for PRA compliance
rights_of_access.applies_to: All Washington state and local agencies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Public records officer is primary point of contact for requests and should facilitate access
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Please direct this request to your public records officer as required by Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.580.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must maintain and make available schedules describing the retention of their public records. This helps requesters understand what records exist and how long they are kept.
rights_of_access.conditions: Schedules must be reasonably current and accessible
rights_of_access.applies_to: All Washington agencies' record retention schedules
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Retention schedules help requesters identify what records should exist
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Please provide your records retention schedule under Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.100 to help identify available records.'

rights_of_access.description: Email and other electronic communications regarding public business are public records subject to disclosure. Agencies cannot use email deletion policies to evade the Public Records Act.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must relate to conduct of government or agency performance; personal emails on agency systems may be exempt
rights_of_access.applies_to: Email and electronic messaging systems used for agency business
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies must preserve email related to public business; deletion policies must comply with retention requirements
rights_of_access.request_tips: For emails: 'Email regarding agency business constitutes public records under Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.070(1). Please search email systems and preserve responsive messages.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies cannot categorically deny requests as 'overbroad' without engaging with requesters to clarify or narrow scope. Agencies have duty to assist requesters in formulating requests that can be fulfilled.
rights_of_access.conditions: Agency must work with requester in good faith; cannot summarily reject without discussion
rights_of_access.applies_to: All requests agencies claim are unclear or overbroad
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Courts require agencies to help requesters craft workable requests rather than rejecting outright
rights_of_access.request_tips: If rejected as overbroad: 'Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.080 requires you to work with me to clarify this request rather than summarily rejecting it as overbroad.'

rights_of_access.description: Even if initial 5-day response is provided, subsequent unreasonable delays in production violate the Act. Agencies must make continuous, good faith efforts to fulfill requests.
rights_of_access.conditions: Delays must be objectively unreasonable; agency must show ongoing good faith efforts
rights_of_access.applies_to: All stages of request fulfillment
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Courts carefully scrutinize whether delays are justified by request complexity or agency failure to prioritize
rights_of_access.request_tips: For delays: 'Wash. Rev. Code § 42.56.520 requires reasonable diligence in fulfilling requests. Please explain what justifies this delay or provide records immediately.'
